content:
Wanted to discuss #6413 since it looks like a really quick fix; what are people's thoughts on changing the color of the flag to match the private message compose flag?

screenshot at sep 05 22-29-09
I'm up for it. Should be an easy thing to undo if we deploy it and people object to it for some reason. The color in the nav bar does seem too dark to me.
Makes a lot of sense, I am actually all for improving this UI significantly.
First step: 'You and' being replaced by icon or some text like 'PM with:'
Or just the whole line being dark and a list of users will make this obvious what it is.

A related PR that I would like people to get behind: https://github.com/zulip/zulip/pull/6101

(see the screenshot in the PR)
For the diff in the screen shot => I am strongly in favor
Can you add a comment like "Please merge this" to the PR? :)
I am also in favor of discussing a more consistent design language with @Brock Whittaker both for the front-end and the mobile.

For example representing a stream in a single way, rather than the multiple variations we have. Maybe a colored hashtag plus the name is enough? Then the same style for the stream input in the compose box
Should I move ahead with changing the flag color and replacing "You and" with "PM with"?
I'll mildly defend "You and", because we use that in narrows.
Also, speaking of 1.7, it's probably worth going through user docs once again to update screenshots before we release
Go ahead and do both, but I'll only merge the color one. For the "PM with" it would be nice to have a PR, even if all it does is help move the debate forward.
I don't know how well "PM with" will internationalize, for example, and some people don't know "PM" as an abbreviation, since I've heard folks say "DM" for direct message.
also, I think a larger redesign of the nav bar is in progress, in which possibly the whole breadcrumb trail is being removed?
Yep, but in my opinion that shouldn't hold up the quick fix to undo the pentagon layout.
I agree with @Steve Howell, just merge it in. There hasn't been a ton of clarity on how to proceed with the nav in recent discussions, and this seems generally like an improvement.
What I am concerned about then is that if we remove the arrows in the breadcrumbs in the nav, we should remove them in the message headers, otherwise it would be inconsistent.
Opened #6417 for "PM with" changes
I guess I should say, I'm not sure I'm in favor of replacing hexagons with straight lines, either in the navbar or in the recipient bars. But seems reasonable to take a poll.
I don't think it looks better from a design perspective but it is more space efficient.
Would it make sense to responsively remove it for mobile web?
I'd generally long-term like them removed everywhere as I strongly feel they look dated, however I'd prefer come up to a slightly better solution in the meanwhile.
Doing it responsively doesn't really make much sense to me. It would be complex to implement, and it would be an inconsistent feel for the users.
I don't know if it would really be complex to implement but I think more importantly complex to maintain, since it just adds more states to the page that can theoretically break in any contribution.
Yeah, that's what I mean re:complexity. :)
Yeah, I agree with the meaning of 'complexity' as in 'not hard, but too much to take care of thus does gets ignored'

Another thing is that the space savings come into play even for a relatively wide laptop view:

pasted image
I think the 'hexagon' and 'arrow' designs usually are tricky, as they often break a bit depending on the browser rendering them, and angles are rarely consistent etc.

I worry that not having the pentagon makes it look pretty unstyled, though.
Also, can we just get rid of the topic breadcrumb without changing the rest?
or just rid of the breadcrumbs entirely without changing the rest? I seem to remember the answer being no, but I forget what the reason was.
The breadcrumbs are useful to know where you're narrowed if you are scrolling the sidebar.
Are you referring to the breadcrumbs on top of the screen (left of search) or the sticky headers?

I agree it looks unstyled now, but I also agree we need to keep breadcrumbs. Perhaps my navbar PR would address this issue since it removes the concept of having both breadcrumbs and the input side by side, which gives more real estate to both?
(Boris: the ones left of search)
Maybe @Steve Howell was referring to the sticky header, thus his concerns are not an issue?
BTW, that is quite helpful to compare the progress when simplifying CSS and styles: http://cssstats.com/
Our official term for the sticky header is the "floating recipient bar."
But there is already a 'sticky header' used in mobile UI for that pattern, also in the iOS and Android APIs

I fixed the navbar breadcrumbs to be square in topic narrows (they're already square in stream narrows and PM narrows). I haven't fixed the FRBs, but I'd prefer them to be square, too, and I'm happy to do the work of making them square before merging my existing PR.
so "sticky header" === FRB
pasted image

This got lost a bit, but what did we feel was useful about the breadcrumbs?
I agree the FRB is great, so I'm only referring to the breadcrumbs to the left of the search magnifying glass.

They tell you, in one place, where you're narrowed, without you having to parse search syntax. The left sidebar mostly tells you where you're narrowed, but it can be invisible at times, and it forces you to scan the whole sidebar to see where you're narrowed, rather than having one single permanent place you look.
Would it be sufficient if the search text were instead represented as pills, with special pills (that always were sorted to left) for stream and topic?

I think that's a defensible approach, but I personally don't like it. I view narrows as significantly different than searches. I actually want the search bar mostly out of my way, unless I'm actually searching for a search term or doing some kind of exotic narrow.
That's fair, and it's true I do have the issue of "am I narrowed to a stream or topic?" pretty often, I just currently don't use the search bar area to figure out the answer.
Would be curious to see your solution, Brock, if you still have it handy (didn't see it in the list of open PRs)
I think we should try switching to pills and see how it feels. It certainly is a better encoding of the state than what we're currently doing.
